episodeTitle: Uprising of the Navigator! For the Unyielding Dream!
episodeTitleJapanese: 航海士の反乱！ゆずれない夢の為に！
episodeTitleRomanized: Kōkaishi no Hanran! Yuzurenai Yume no Tame ni!
description: The Straw Hat Pirates fish a traveling salesman named Rice Rice out of the water. He tries to sell his wares to the crew, and Nami acquires Millennium Paper for her cartography work. The episode focuses on Nami's dream to map the entire world, featuring flashbacks to her childhood with Bell-mère in Cocoyasi Village. As Nami attempts to draw maps of the islands they've visited, her crewmates' antics repeatedly interrupt her work.

events.title: Rice Rice's Debut
events.description: The Straw Hat crew discovers a strange armored figure floating in the water. Luffy fishes him out, revealing Rice Rice, a traveling salesman from the Den Den Mushi Mail Order company who was lost at sea during a delivery.
events.significance: Introduces a comedic filler character who serves as the catalyst for Nami obtaining the materials she needs to pursue her dream of cartography. Rice Rice's appearance sets up the episode's focus on Nami's ambitions.

quotes.text: Nahahhahahahaha! Thank you for saving me! I'm Rice Rice from the Den Den Mushi Mail Order!
quotes.speaker: Rice Rice
quotes.context: Rice Rice introduces himself after being rescued by the Straw Hats

events.title: Den Den Mushi Mail Order Introduction
events.description: Rice Rice explains the Den Den Mushi Mail Order service, a traveling sales system where salesmen use Escar (giant snails) to deliver products across the seas. He demonstrates various products from his catalog to the curious crew.
events.significance: Expands the world-building of One Piece by showing how commerce and trade work across the seas. The Den Den Mushi Mail Order represents a creative use of the series' unique snail-based communication technology.

events.title: Rice Rice's Product Demonstrations
events.description: Rice Rice demonstrates various products from his catalog including the Buru Buru Blade, Ab-Ab Slider mechanical mouse, Golden Fish exercise device, Mero Mero Juice, and kitchen knives. The crew reacts with varying levels of interest and skepticism to each item.
events.significance: Provides comic relief while establishing Rice Rice's character as a stereotypical pushy salesman. These gag products showcase the humorous side of One Piece's world and give the crew members moments to react in character.

events.title: Nami Acquires Millennium Paper
events.description: Nami discovers that Rice Rice has Millennium Paper in his inventory - special durable paper that won't fade for a thousand years when exposed to sunlight. Despite Rice Rice's attempts to drive up the price, Nami negotiates and purchases a large supply of this paper for her mapmaking.
events.significance: This is the pivotal moment that allows Nami to begin seriously pursuing her dream of creating a world map. The Millennium Paper represents the professional-grade materials needed for maps that will last and be reliable, showing Nami's commitment to her craft.

quotes.text: This paper is perfect for making maps! It will last a thousand years without fading!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami realizes she's found the ideal material for her cartography work

events.title: Nami's Childhood Dream Flashback
events.description: Nami has a flashback to her childhood in Cocoyasi Village. Young Nami stands on a cliff with Bell-mère and Nojiko, where she asks her adoptive mother 'What lies beyond the sea?' Bell-mère encourages Nami's curiosity and her dream to travel the world and create maps of everywhere she goes.
events.significance: This flashback reinforces the origins of Nami's dream and shows Bell-mère's support for her ambitions. It provides emotional depth to Nami's character and explains why cartography means so much to her - it represents freedom, exploration, and the world beyond the confines of Cocoyasi Village.

quotes.speaker: Young Nami
quotes.context: Nami expresses her childhood curiosity about the world beyond her village

events.title: Bell-mère Encourages Nami's Mapmaking
events.description: In the flashback, Bell-mère praises young Nami's first attempt at drawing a map of their island, calling it the first step toward her dream of mapping the entire world. Bell-mère gives Nami the confidence that she can truly achieve her ambitious goal.
events.significance: This moment establishes the foundation of Nami's cartography skills and shows Bell-mère's crucial role in nurturing her dream. Bell-mère's encouragement gave Nami the faith to pursue what seemed like an impossible dream, making her current work all the more meaningful.

quotes.text: This is wonderful, Nami! This is the first step of your dream to map the world!
quotes.speaker: Bell-mère
quotes.context: Bell-mère encourages young Nami's first mapmaking attempt

events.title: Nami Begins Creating Her World Map
events.description: Inspired by her flashback and armed with the Millennium Paper, Nami decides to start making her dream of drawing a map of the world a reality. She settles down to draw detailed maps of the recent islands they've visited: Little Garden, Drum Island, and Arabasta.
events.significance: This is a significant character moment where Nami takes concrete action toward her lifelong dream. Now free from Arlong's control and traveling with a crew that supports her, she can finally pursue cartography seriously. This represents her growth and newfound freedom.

quotes.text: Now I can finally start working on my real dream - to draw a map of the entire world!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami commits to beginning her world map project

events.title: Crew Interrupts Nami's Work
events.description: As Nami tries to concentrate on her mapmaking, her crewmates repeatedly interrupt her with their usual antics. Luffy, Usopp, and Chopper's playful behavior, Sanji's cooking, and Zoro's training all create distractions that frustrate the navigator.
events.significance: This comedic sequence highlights the reality of life aboard the Going Merry - it's chaotic and noisy, making focused work difficult. It shows the contrast between Nami's serious dedication to her craft and the rest of the crew's more relaxed attitude, creating humor from their different personalities.

events.title: Chopper's Fearful Contrition
events.description: When Chopper accidentally interrupts Nami's work, he becomes extremely fearful and contrite, apologizing profusely and showing deep concern about upsetting her. His innocent reaction demonstrates his gentle nature and desire to be a good crewmate.
events.significance: This moment showcases Chopper's endearing personality and his developing relationships with the crew. His fear of upsetting Nami reveals both his kind heart and his inexperience with social dynamics, having recently joined the crew.

events.title: Nami Declares Navigator's Mutiny
events.description: Frustrated by the constant interruptions, Nami playfully declares a 'Navigator's Mutiny,' asserting her right to have peace and quiet to work on her maps. She demands that the crew respect her need for concentration.
events.significance: This humorous moment ties into the episode's title and shows Nami's assertiveness in standing up for her needs. It demonstrates the crew dynamics where members must balance their individual pursuits with the chaos of group living.

quotes.text: This is a Navigator's Mutiny! I need quiet to work on my maps!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami demands peace and quiet from her rowdy crewmates

events.title: Zoro Questions Sanji's Work Distribution
events.description: Zoro observes that Robin is not being asked to help with ship duties and questions Sanji's sexist exemption of female crew members from work. This leads to a brief argument between Zoro and Sanji about fairness and work distribution on the ship.
events.significance: This moment provides insight into the crew's work dynamics and highlights Zoro's sense of fairness versus Sanji's chivalrous (but outdated) views on gender roles. It's a minor character moment that shows the ongoing tension between these two crewmates.

events.title: Robin's Quiet Observation
events.description: Throughout the episode, Nico Robin remains relatively quiet and observant, barely speaking or participating in the crew's antics. She watches the dynamics unfold without inserting herself into the chaos.
events.significance: This characterizes Robin's early dynamic with the crew. Still a new member, she hasn't fully integrated and remains somewhat detached from the group's playful behavior. This distance reflects her complicated past and cautious approach to forming bonds.

events.title: Rice Rice Flees in Fear
events.description: When Rice Rice finally realizes he's aboard a pirate ship with the notorious Straw Hat Luffy, he becomes terrified and flees, abandoning much of his inventory in his haste to escape on his Escar.
events.significance: This comedic moment shows how the Straw Hats are perceived by ordinary people as dangerous pirates, despite their friendly nature. Rice Rice's fear contrasts with the crew's actual kindness, creating humor from the misconception.

events.title: Surviving the Tornado
events.description: The Going Merry encounters a deadly tornado at sea. The crew must work together to navigate through the dangerous weather phenomenon, with Nami providing crucial guidance as navigator.
events.significance: This action sequence serves to remind viewers of the dangers of sea travel and showcases Nami's skills as a navigator. It also provides exciting visual spectacle for what is otherwise a character-focused filler episode.

events.title: Nami Completes Her First Maps
events.description: Despite all the interruptions and challenges, Nami successfully completes detailed maps of Little Garden, Drum Island, and Arabasta. She looks at her finished work with pride, knowing these are the first real steps toward her dream of mapping the entire world.
events.significance: This ending provides a satisfying conclusion to the episode's central theme. Nami's success in creating these maps despite obstacles represents her determination and skill. It's a small but meaningful victory in her lifelong quest, and symbolizes her freedom to pursue her dreams.

quotes.text: These maps are my first real steps toward mapping the entire world. Bell-mère, I'm finally doing it!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami reflects on completing her first professional maps

quotes.text: Nahahhahahahaha! Thank you for saving me! I'm Rice Rice from the Den Den Mushi Mail Order!
quotes.speaker: Rice Rice
quotes.context: Rice Rice introduces himself after being rescued

quotes.text: This paper is perfect for making maps! It will last a thousand years without fading!
quotes.speaker: Nami
Young Nami
quotes.context: Nami's childhood curiosity about the world

quotes.text: This is wonderful, Nami! This is the first step of your dream to map the world!
quotes.speaker: Bell-mère

quotes.text: Now I can finally start working on my real dream - to draw a map of the entire world!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami commits to her world map project

quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami demands peace from her crewmates

quotes.text: These maps are my first real steps toward mapping the entire world. Bell-mère, I'm finally doing it!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami reflects on completing her first professional maps

themes.description: The episode centers on Nami's lifelong dream of mapping the entire world. Despite numerous obstacles and interruptions, she perseveres and takes concrete steps toward achieving her goal.
themes.symbolism: The Millennium Paper symbolizes permanence and legacy - Nami's maps will last for generations, making her mark on the world. It represents the transition from childhood dreams to real, professional work.

themes.description: Nami's ability to finally pursue her cartography seriously represents her newfound freedom from Arlong's control. The episode contrasts her past constraints with her current liberty to chase her dreams.
themes.symbolism: The wide-open sea and Nami's maps represent unlimited possibilities and the freedom to explore without boundaries.

themes.description: Bell-mère's encouragement in the flashbacks shows the importance of having someone believe in your dreams. Even after her death, Bell-mère's support continues to motivate Nami.
themes.symbolism: Nami creating maps honors Bell-mère's memory and the confidence she instilled. Each map is a tribute to the woman who taught her to dream big.

themes.description: The episode humorously explores the challenge of pursuing serious work while living in a chaotic, fun-loving environment. Nami must find ways to balance her professional ambitions with crew life.
themes.symbolism: The constant interruptions represent the reality that dreams aren't pursued in isolation - they happen alongside daily life and relationships.

characterSpotlights.development: This episode provides deep insight into Nami's character, showing the origins of her cartography dream and her determination to achieve it. We see her growth from a girl trapped by Arlong to a free woman actively pursuing her ambitions. The flashbacks with Bell-mère add emotional depth and show the foundation of her confidence.
keyActions: Negotiates with Rice Rice for Millennium Paper
Has flashback to childhood with Bell-mère
Decides to begin creating world map
Draws maps of Little Garden, Drum Island, and Arabasta
Declares Navigator's Mutiny for peace and quiet
Successfully completes her first professional maps
quotes: This paper is perfect for making maps! It will last a thousand years without fading!
Now I can finally start working on my real dream - to draw a map of the entire world!
This is a Navigator's Mutiny! I need quiet to work on my maps!
These maps are my first real steps toward mapping the entire world. Bell-mère, I'm finally doing it!

characterSpotlights.role: Guest character and catalyst for episode events
characterSpotlights.development: Rice Rice is introduced as a stereotypical pushy salesman with a distinctive laugh and dishonest business practices. Despite being saved by the Straw Hats, he immediately tries to profit from them, showing his opportunistic nature. His eventual fear and flight when realizing they're pirates provides comic relief.
keyActions: Gets rescued by the Straw Hats
Introduces Den Den Mushi Mail Order service
Demonstrates various products to the crew
Attempts to overcharge Nami for Millennium Paper
Realizes he's aboard a pirate ship
Flees in terror, abandoning his inventory
quotes: Nahahhahahahaha! Thank you for saving me! I'm Rice Rice from the Den Den Mushi Mail Order!

characterSpotlights.development: Though appearing only in flashbacks, Bell-mère's role is crucial to the episode's emotional core. She is shown as a supportive mother figure who encouraged Nami's dreams and gave her the confidence to pursue them.
keyActions: Listens to young Nami's questions about the world
Encourages Nami's ambitious dream to map the world
Gives Nami confidence in her abilities
quotes: This is wonderful, Nami! This is the first step of your dream to map the world!

mangaDifferences.difference: This entire episode is anime-original filler and does not appear in the manga. It was created to give the manga time to progress ahead of the anime adaptation.

trivia.fact: This is the final episode to use 'Shining ray' by Janne da Arc as the ending theme. The ending ran from episodes 119-132, a total of 14 episodes.
Episode 132 is a filler episode that was created during the Post-Arabasta Arc to allow the manga to build up more content before the anime continued with the Jaya Arc.
The episode aired on November 10, 2002 in Japan, approximately 7.5 years before its US broadcast on May 11, 2010.
The Millennium Paper that Nami obtains is described as lasting a thousand years without fading - a wish-fulfillment item for any cartographer, artist, or writer working with paper.
This episode features flashbacks to Cocoyasi Village and Bell-mère, calling back to the emotional Arlong Park Arc (episodes 31-44) that established Nami's backstory.
The Den Den Mushi Mail Order service expands the world-building around the series' iconic snail-based communication and transportation systems.

Episode 132 is part of a pattern in the Post-Arabasta filler arc where each episode focuses on a different Straw Hat crew member's dream - Episode 131 focused on Chopper's medical aspirations, and this episode focuses on Nami's cartography dreams.

sources.title: Never Watched One Piece - Episode 132 Review
